head.title: Crazy Weather Got Started in Kuwait

hedline.hl1: Crazy Weather Got Started in Kuwait

block.p: "Northeast's Strange Weather: Don't Blame It All on the Volcano" (Science Times, Aug. 4) omits what may be the key factor in this area's changing weather patterns: each of the 500 wells that were set ablaze in the oil fields of Kuwait.

According to information published by Friends of the Earth International (summer 1991), on June 8, 1991, the Friends of the Earth team, flying 120 miles south of Kuwait, "found the plume had reached an altitude of 16,400 feet."

"Northeast's Strange Weather: Don't Blame It All on the Volcano" (Science Times, Aug. 4) omits what may be the key factor in this area's changing weather patterns: each of the 500 wells that were set ablaze in the oil fields of Kuwait.

According to information published by Friends of the Earth International (summer 1991), on June 8, 1991, the Friends of the Earth team, flying 120 miles south of Kuwait, "found the plume had reached an altitude of 16,400 feet."

The report went on to state that the climatologist Adam Twombly was concerned by "the angle of the plume's trajectory," which indicated even greater "lofting" the farther the plume traveled. "Twombly projected that 'some of the plume reaches more than 50,000 feet.' The concern is that if the plume reaches altitudes of 40,000 feet, there could be global climate changes."

Given the relevancy and seriousness of these facts, why was there no mention of the Kuwaiti oil fires in your article? You owe it to your readers and to scientific accuracy to look into the premise. JOSEPH COPLAN New York, Aug. 9, 1992 The writer is a consultant to industrial companies that have advanced systems for oil-water separation and oil spill cleanup.
